questions.question: Which of the following is a common joint pathology associated with the advanced stages of rheumatoid arthritis?

options.B: Fibrous or bony ankylosis and joint subluxation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Fibrous or bony ankylosis and joint subluxation Explanation: Chronic inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis leads to the destruction of cartilage and bone, which can cause the joint to become immobile i.e. ankylosis, either due to fibrous tissue or actual bony fusion. Joint subluxation can also occur as a result of ligament and tendon damage, leading to misalignment of the joint. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a systemic disease. It is the most common cause of chronic inflammatory joint disease. Women >> Men. Common age group: Fourth or fifth decades of life. Etiology: Genetic Predisposition: Strong association with histocompatibility markers HLA-DR4/HLA-DR1. HLA-DR4 is found in ~70% of people with RA. Infectious Agents: Possible involvement of mycoplasma, clostridium, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in genetically predisposed individuals. Pathogenesis: Immune Activation: APC (Antigen-presenting cells)/T-cell interaction initiates immune response and release of cytokines. Cell proliferation occurs in the synovium. Cytokine Involvement: Cytokines activate macrophages and B-cells. B-cell activation leads to anti-IgG autoantibody production. Chronic Inflammation: Immune complexes deposit in synovial joints, enhancing inflammation. Production of proteolytic enzymes, prostaglandins, TNF, and IL-1. Cartilage matrix depletion and bone damage occur due to inflammatory factors. Synovial Changes: Synovium becomes edematous, infiltrated, and filled with fibrin exudates. Hypertrophied synovium surrounds articular cartilage, forming a pannus. Cartilage loses its smooth surface and becomes eroded; pannus extends into subchondral bone. Joint Deformities: Deformities due to muscle spasms, fibrosis, and soft tissue changes. Advanced disease leads to fibrous/bony ankylosis and subluxation of joints. Osteoporosis develops in adjacent bones, and peri-articular tissues become edematous. Osteophyte formation (Option A): It refers to the development of bone spurs, commonly seen in osteoarthritis (OA) rather than rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes (Option C): These nodes are associated with osteoarthritis. Heberden's nodes occur at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, while Bouchard's nodes occur at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Bone cyst formation (Option D): They can occur in osteoarthritis due to bone remodeling, but they are not a common feature of rheumatoid arthritis.

A 42-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, primarily affecting her hands and wrists. She reports that the stiffness is worse in the morning and lasts for over an hour. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling in multiple small joints, and her grip strength is reduced. An X-ray of the hands is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR, C-reactive protein (CRP), positive rheumatoid factor (RF), and normal liver function tests and complete blood count. After temporary symptom relief with NSAIDs which of the following is the first line of treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Methotrexate Explanation: The clinical manifestations, X-ray findings (marginal bone erosion in the left 5th metacarpophalangeal joint and joint space narrowing with marginal bone erosion in the right 4th and 5th proximal interphalangeal joints) and blood investigations are consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis in patients with active disease for reducing disease activity and preventing further joint damage. X-ray: Early changes- soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis. In later stages- marginal bony erosions and narrowing of the articular space. questions.question: In primary osteoarthritis, systemic and mechanical factors interact to trigger the early stages of cartilage degeneration. Which of the following is the earliest pathological change observed in osteoarthritis?

options.B: Increased water content in the cartilage

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Increased water content in the cartilage Explanation: The first change observed in osteoarthritis is increased water content (microscopic change) and loss of proteoglycans from the cartilage matrix, weakening the cartilage structure. Osteoarthritis (OA): It is the most common form of arthritis in the world. It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet. Types: Primary OA: It occurs in a joint de novo without any underlying cause. It occurs in old age, mainly in the weight-bearing joints (knee and hip). Secondary OA: An underlying primary disease of the joint leads to degeneration of the joint. Commonly occurs at the hip. Trauma or injury, congenital joint disorders, inflammatory arthritis, avascular necrosis, infectious arthritis, Paget disease, osteopetrosis, osteochondritis dissecans, metabolic disorders (hemochromatosis, Wilson’s disease), hemoglobinopathy, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, or Marfan syndrome. Major risk factors for OA: Systemic predisposition: Genetics Age Gender- Women, especially post-menopausal Diet and obesity Local biomechanical factors: Abnormal joint shape and size Previous injury/trauma Neuromuscular problems Obesity Loading/occupational factors Pathogenesis: Systemic and local mechanical factors interact to initiate the osteoarthritis process. Primarily articular cartilage is affected. The first change observed is increased water content (microscopic change) and loss of proteoglycans from the cartilage matrix, weakening the cartilage structure. (Option B) Progressive softening and disintegration of articular cartilage occurs due to continued mechanical stress. As the cartilage wears away, the underlying subchondral bone becomes exposed. (Option D ruled out) Associated with new growth of cartilage and bone at joint margins forming osteophytes. (Option C ruled out) Loose flakes of cartilage can incite synovial inflammation , leading to capsular thickening and joint deformity. (Option A ruled out) Often, only one compartment of the joint is more affected. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 91, 94, 95, 96, 374

questions.question: A 58-year-old female with a 15-year history of diabetes presents with a chronic charcot foot deformity in her right foot, accompanied by recurrent ulcerations. She has previously undergone treatment with total contact casting but continues to have instability and pain. What is the next best step for her?

options.A: Management with offloading and regular follow-up
options.C: Schedule surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation
options.D: Refer for amputation of the affected foot

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Schedule surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation Explanation: Surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation is indicated for patients with chronic Charcot foot deformities who experience instability and recurrent ulcerations despite conservative treatment. It will effectively stabilize the affected joints, alleviate pain, and reduce the risk of further ulceration, making it a definitive management strategy. Restore a plantigrade foot, improving the patient's overall function and quality of life. Treatment Details General Treatment Vascular Management: Vasodilators improve blood flow Pentoxifylline enhances RBC flexibility, promotes wound healing, and maintains vascularity. Infection Control : Antibiotics are essential for managing and preventing infection. Acute Arthropathy Immobilization: Minimizes movement to protect the affected area Total Contact Casting (TCC) : Provides pressure relief while allowing mobility Encase foot and lower leg, redistributing weight with regular checks for fit(weekly) & replace them every 2 weeks. The aim of TCC is to keep the patient mobile Chronic arthropathy Rest: Essential for recovery and reducing stress on the affected area Braces : Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) Brace supports mobility and redistributes pressure Orthotics: Charcot Restraint Orthotic Walker prevents further damage to Charcot’s joint. Surgical Treatment Includes Open Reduction Internal Fixation (ORIF) for complex fractures Excision of bony prominences Reconstruction to restore structure Arthrodesis to fuse joints Amputation in severe cases. Management with offloading and regular follow-up (Option A): While offloading is important, this patient has already failed conservative treatment and requires a more definitive solution. Initiate pharmacologic therapy with bisphosphonates (Option B) : Pharmacologic therapy may help reduce bone resorption but does not address the underlying deformity or instability. Refer for amputation of the affected foot (Option D): This should only be considered if all other options have failed or if the patient's condition is unsuitable for further surgery. In this case, surgical intervention is warranted.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy with a history of severe hemophilia A presents with recurrent episodes of knee swelling and pain. On examination, his knee shows significant effusion and tenderness, and the physician suspects pathologic changes in the joint. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the joint changes observed in this condition?

options.A: Increased osteoclast activity leading to bone resorption
options.B: Hyperplastic vascularity and inflammation in the synovial membrane
options.C: Accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint space
options.D: Immune-mediated damage to the cartilage due to systemic inflammation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hyperplastic vascularity and inflammation in the synovial membrane membrane is characteristic of haemophilic arthropathy, resulting from recurrent bleeds leading to chronic joint changes. Etiopathogenesis: Coagulation Pathway Altered intrinsic pathway leading to bleeding tendency Types of Hemophilia Type A (Absence of factor VIII, 85%) Type B (Absence of factor IX, 15%) Primary Cause Chronic and recurrent exposure of articular cartilage and synovium to metabolized blood products Consequences of Blood in Joint Hypervascular synovial hypertrophy Chronic synovitis Articular cartilage damage Bony hypertrophy Subchondral cysts Joint surface loses its luster and becomes eroded in” Rivet-like tracts” In end-stage disease, the densely pigment-stained hyperplastic membrane undergoes metaplasia to fibrous tissue, and contractures develop, eventually leading to fibrous ankylosis Increased osteoclast activity leading to bone resorption (Option A): is more relevant in conditions like osteoporosis Accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint space (Option C): are associated with gout Immune-mediated damage to the cartilage due to systemic inflammation (Option D): occurs in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis where the immune system attacks joint tissues, leading to inflammation and cartilage destruction.

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy with severe hemophilia A presents to the emergency department with a swollen, painful right knee after falling while playing a few hours ago. His mother reports that he has had similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is the next best step?

options.A: Administer oral NSAIDs and discharge home
options.B: Perform joint aspiration and factor replacement
options.C: Immobilize the knee in a flexed position

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Perform joint aspiration and factor replacement Explanation: This is a case of acute hemarthrosis as noted by the time of onset. In acute hemarthrosis in hemophilia, the immediate focus should be on an aspiration to relieve pressure and pain, combined with factor replacement to correct the coagulation defect. Management Acute Hemarthrosis Aspiration: Aggressive management with aspiration of the joint. Factor Replacement : Regular replacement of clotting factors (e.g., Factor VIII/IX) to prevent further bleeding. NSAIDs: Use of Cox-2 inhibitors or ibuprofen for pain relief. Bupivacaine & Corticosteroids : Instillation during aspiration to reduce rebleeding risk. Bed Rest & Immobilization: Strict bed rest and limb immobilization in extension. Emergent Considerations: Special care for immature hip to prevent osteonecrosis. Primary Prophylaxis Initiated in infancy to prevent future hemarthroses and long-term disability. Surgery (Elective) Pre-Surgery Factor Replacement: Infusion 2 hours before surgery to achieve 100% factor activity continuous infusion to maintain >60% during and after surgery. Post-Surgery Monitoring: Check factor levels immediately after and then every 1-2 days. Chronic Arthritis Synovectomy: Open or arthroscopic synovectomy for recurrent hemarthrosis recommended if bleeding occurs >3 times in 6 months. Radiosynovectomy: For patients with multiple joint involvement or inhibitors. With Yttrium 90 silicate or Phosphorus 31 colloid Surgical Principles: (Post & Telfer) Tight wound closure No electrocautery, wound suction Avoid certain medications post-op. Specific Surgical Interventions Knee: TKA indicated in advanced cases; patellar resurfacing recommended. Elbow: Radial head excision with synovectomy for recurrent hemarthrosis. Hip: Total hip replacement for good outcomes. Shoulder: Arthrodesis or prosthetic replacement options. Ankle : Arthrodesis for chronic arthritis. Flexion Contractures Correction: Recommended correction of flexion contractures >30° before surgery. Hamstring Release: For knee flexion contractures <45° not amenable to conservative treatment. Osteotomy: Severe cases may require supracondylar osteotomy. Complications: Neurologic Complications: Bleeding into the central nervous system (CNS). Hemorrhage into major peripheral nerves. Joint Complications: Stiffness of affected joints. Development of contractures. Arthritis due to recurrent bleeding episodes. Other Complications: Compartment syndrome due to increased pressure from bleeding. Blood-borne infections related to repeated procedures or factor replacement. Administer oral NSAIDs and discharge home (Option B): While NSAIDs can help with pain relief, they do not address the underlying issue of hemarthrosis. Immobilize the knee in a flexed position (Option C): Immobilization is important, but it should be done in extension to prevent further complications and allow for proper healing. Flexing the knee could exacerbate swelling and pain. Refer for immediate surgical synovectomy (Option D):

questions.question: A 38-year-old female with a history of psoriasis develops joint pain. Which of the following genetic markers is most commonly associated with psoriatic arthritis, but present in only 50- 60% of cases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) HLA-B27 Explanation: HLA-B27 is associated with psoriatic arthritis though it is present in only about 50-60% of cases. Psoriatic arthritis It is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. The usual age at onset is 30–50 years. It is usually seronegative (no rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies). 20% of patients with Psoriasis develop arthritis. Etiology: Strong genetic component. Associated with HLA B27 - only in 50-60%. Pathology: Chronic synovitis leads to cell infiltration and exudate, progressing to fibrosis. Severe cartilage and bone destruction. questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the clinical manifestation of psoriatic arthritis?

options.A: It can present with both distal interphalangeal joint arthritis and spondylitis.
options.B: Enthesitis, especially at the Achilles tendon insertion may be present.
options.C: Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with symmetrical arthritis in large joints.
options.D: Arthritis mutilans can lead to severe deformities in the fingers and toes.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with symmetrical arthritis in large joints. particularly affecting smaller joints like the distal interphalangeal joints, rather than exhibiting symmetrical involvement in large joints. Clinical Manifestations: Arthritis: Asymmetrical oligoarthritis- common presentation Symmetrical arthritis in some patients (Option C) Distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) arthritis (Option A ruled out) Arthritis mutilans - Fingers and toes are severely deformed due to erosion and instability of the interphalangeal joints. (Option D ruled out) Interphalangeal arthritis and tenosynovitis Sacroiliitis and spondylitis (Option A ruled out) Heel pain (enthesitis) (Option B ruled out) Ocular manifestation: Ocular inflammation- uveitis Skin manifestations: Sharply demarcated, erythematous plaque with silver scale. Guttate lesions are small, erythematous papules generalized over the entire body surface area.

questions.question: A 38-year-old male with a 10-year history of psoriasis presents to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in his fingers and lower back stiffness for the past several months. On examination, there is swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) of both hands, and tenderness in the sacroiliac region. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are elevated, but rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are negative. Which of the following radiological findings is NOT commonly associated with his condition?

options.A: Erosive changes and joint space narrowing
options.B: New bone formation and bony ankylosis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Periarticular osteopenia with marginal erosions Explanation: The patient’s clinical manifestation with a background history of psoriasis is consistent with a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. Periarticular osteopenia with marginal erosions is more commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis rather than psoriatic arthritis. Blood investigations in Psoriatic arthritis : There are no laboratory tests specifically for psoriatic arthritis. Raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Negative Rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. HLA-B27 is present in 50–60%. Radiological findings: Erosive changes, gross joint destruction, joint space narrowing. (Option A ruled out) Erosive changes, new bone formation, bony ankylosis, and joint osteolysis in hands and feet. (Option B ruled out) Erosive osteoarthritis Axial bones and joints - sacroiliitis and spondylitis; formation of syndesmophytes (ossification of the annulus fibrosis). (Option D ruled out) USG and MRI are useful for detecting synovitis. Treatment: Medical: NSAIDs Immuno suppressive agents- methotrexate and TNF inhibitors Local glucocorticoid injections Physiotherapy Surgery: For unstable joints. Arthrodesis procedure.
